name: Two decades (and a bit) of Football

data.title: Premier League
data.description: Major historical records for the English top flight, including the dominant eras of Man Utd, Man City, and Liverpool.

data.title: Manchester United
data.description: One of England's most successful clubs, transitioning from the Ferguson era to a long rebuilding phase.

data.title: Sir Alex Ferguson Reign
data.description: The definitive era of the club, winning 13 league titles and a 2008 Champions League title.

data.title: UCL Champions
data.description: United defeat Chelsea on penalties in Moscow to win their third European Cup.

data.title: Ronaldo Record Transfer
data.description: Cristiano Ronaldo leaves for Real Madrid for a world-record fee of £80 million.

data.title: Ferguson Retirement
data.description: Sir Alex Ferguson manages his 1,500th and final game, a 5-5 draw with West Brom.

data.title: Ruben Amorim Era
data.description: Manchester United appoint Ruben Amorim to lead a new tactical era for the club.

data.title: Liverpool FC
data.description: The resurgence of the Reds into a global powerhouse under Klopp and the transition to Arne Slot.

data.title: Miracle of Istanbul
data.description: Liverpool recover from 3-0 down at half-time to beat AC Milan in the UCL final.

data.title: Jurgen Klopp Era
data.description: A golden era resulting in a Premier League title, a Champions League, and multiple cups.

data.title: Anfield Main Stand Open
data.description: Liverpool complete the expansion of the Main Stand, increasing capacity significantly.

data.title: PL Champions
data.description: Liverpool secure their first league title in 30 years, finishing with 99 points.

data.title: Manchester City
data.description: The rise of the Citizens following the 2008 takeover to become multi-time champions.

data.title: ADUG Takeover
data.description: The Abu Dhabi United Group buys the club, initiating a massive investment program.

data.title: Aguerooooo Goal
data.description: Sergio Aguero scores at 93:20 to win the league title in the final seconds.

data.title: Pep Guardiola Era
data.description: Guardiola implements a new philosophy, winning four consecutive titles (2021-2024).

data.title: The Treble
data.description: City defeat Inter Milan to win the UCL and complete a historic continental treble.

data.title: Leicester City Miracle
data.description: Leicester City win the Premier League at 5000/1 odds, the biggest shock in history.

data.title: Eredivisie
data.description: History of the Dutch top tier, focused on the Big Three and unique title winners.

data.title: AFC Ajax
data.description: The Amsterdam club's era of youth development and return to European prominence.

data.title: Frank de Boer Reign
data.description: De Boer leads Ajax to four consecutive Eredivisie titles between 2011 and 2014.

data.title: Cruyff Arena Renaming
data.description: The Amsterdam Arena is officially renamed the Johan Cruyff Arena to honor the legend.

data.title: UCL Semi-Final Heartbreak
data.description: Ajax fall to Tottenham in the final seconds, ending a historic run to the semi-finals.

data.title: PSV Eindhoven
data.description: The Eindhoven giants' periods of dominance and recent record-breaking performance.

data.title: Phillip Cocu Reign
data.description: Cocu leads PSV to three Eredivisie titles, breaking the Ajax dominance.

data.title: 25th Eredivisie Title
data.description: PSV clinch the title with a dominant season under Peter Bosz, losing only once.

data.title: Feyenoord
data.description: The Rotterdam side's revival from financial trouble to champions under Kuyt and Slot.

data.title: The Kuyt Hat-trick
data.description: Dirk Kuyt scores three to win Feyenoord their first title in 18 years.

data.title: Arne Slot Era
data.description: Slot transforms Feyenoord's style, winning the 2023 title and a KNVB Cup.

data.title: AZ Alkmaar Title
data.description: Louis van Gaal leads AZ to a surprise title, the first outside the Big Three since 1981.

data.title: Bundesliga
data.description: German football records, characterized by Bayern's long reign and the rise of rivals.

data.title: Bayern Munich
data.description: The most successful German club, dominating the league for over a decade.

data.title: Allianz Arena Move
data.description: Bayern move from the Olympiastadion to the new, color-changing Allianz Arena.

data.title: UCL Champions
data.description: Bayern beat Dortmund 2-1 at Wembley to win the UCL and secure the first German treble.

data.title: 11 Consecutive Titles
data.description: Bayern win every Bundesliga title for 11 years, a record in major European leagues.

data.title: Borussia Dortmund
data.description: The club of the 'Yellow Wall', known for high-octane football and developing stars.

data.title: Jurgen Klopp Era
data.description: Klopp wins two Bundesliga titles and reaches a Champions League final.

data.title: Team Bus Bombing
data.description: A targeted attack on the team bus before a UCL match against Monaco.

data.title: Bayer Leverkusen
data.description: The transformation from 'Neverkusen' to undefeated champions.

data.title: Xabi Alonso Era
data.description: Alonso takes Leverkusen to their first-ever league title and an unbeaten season.

data.title: Invincible Title
data.description: Leverkusen clinch the Bundesliga, finishing the entire league season undefeated.

data.title: Primera Division
data.description: Records for Spain's top flight, featuring the Messi-Ronaldo rivalry era.

data.title: Real Madrid
data.description: The era of the Galacticos, the Decima, and the three-peat UCL winners.

data.title: Ronaldo Signing
data.description: Cristiano Ronaldo joins for £80m, beginning a record-shattering 9-year stint.

data.title: La Decima
data.description: Real Madrid win their 10th European Cup, defeating Atletico in extra time.

data.title: Zinedine Zidane Reign
data.description: Zidane leads the club to an unprecedented three consecutive UCL titles.

data.title: FC Barcelona
data.description: The tiki-taka revolution and the peak of the Lionel Messi era.

data.title: Pep Guardiola Era
data.description: Barca win 14 trophies in 4 years, including two UCL titles and the 2009 sextuple.

data.title: Messi Farewell
data.description: Lionel Messi leaves the club due to financial crisis, joining PSG.

data.title: Camp Nou Rebuild
data.description: Barcelona move to the Olympic Stadium while the Camp Nou undergoes massive renovation.

data.title: Atletico Madrid
data.description: The emergence of Atletico as the 'Third Force' in Spanish football.

data.title: Diego Simeone Era
data.description: The longest-serving manager in Europe, turning Atleti into defensive masters.

data.title: Metropolitano Opening
data.description: Atleti move from the Vicente Calderon to the modern Wanda Metropolitano.

data.title: Serie A
data.description: Records for the Italian league, from the Calciopoli scandal to the Napoli revival.

data.title: Juventus
data.description: Italy's 'Old Lady', from relegation to Serie B to nine straight titles.

data.title: Calciopoli Relegation
data.description: Juventus are stripped of titles and relegated to Serie B for match-fixing.

data.title: Juventus Stadium Opening
data.description: Juventus open the first modern, club-owned stadium in Italy.

data.title: The 9-Year Scudetto Run
data.description: Juventus win every Serie A title from 2012 to 2020.

data.title: Inter Milan
data.description: The Nerazzurri's rollercoaster of the 2010 Treble and recent return to stars.

data.title: Jose Mourinho Era
data.description: Mourinho leads Inter to the first and only Italian treble in 2010.

data.title: The Second Star Title
data.description: Inter win their 20th league title, earning the second star on their crest.

data.title: AC Milan
data.description: The Rossoneri's European triumphs and the 2022 return to league glory.

data.title: Athens Victory
data.description: Milan defeat Liverpool 2-1 to win their 7th European Cup.

data.title: Scudetto After 11 Years
data.description: Milan win the league on the final day, sparking massive celebrations.

data.title: Napoli Title Glory
data.description: Napoli win their first league title since 1990, leading to a city-wide party.

data.title: International Football
data.description: Global and continental national team competitions, including World Cups and Euros.

data.title: 2006 World Cup
data.description: Hosted by Germany, concluding with Italy's victory over France.

data.title: Italy World Champions
data.description: Italy beat France on penalties; Zidane is sent off for a headbutt.

data.title: Euro 2008
data.description: Hosted by Austria and Switzerland, won by a dominant Spanish side.

data.title: 2010 World Cup
data.description: The first World Cup in Africa, famous for the vuvuzela and Spain's win.

data.title: Euro 2012
data.description: Poland and Ukraine host; Spain becomes the first to defend the Euro title.

data.title: 2014 World Cup
data.description: Hosted by Brazil, featuring the historic 7-1 semi-final loss of the hosts.

data.title: Germany World Champions
data.description: Mario Gotze scores in the 113th minute to beat Argentina 1-0.

data.title: Euro 2016
data.description: Hosted by France and won by Portugal, their first major international trophy.

data.title: 2018 World Cup
data.description: Hosted by Russia; France wins their second star with a 4-2 win in the final.

data.title: Euro 2020
data.description: Delayed until 2021; held across Europe and won by Italy at Wembley.

data.title: 2022 World Cup
data.description: Hosted by Qatar; Lionel Messi finally lifts the trophy for Argentina.

data.title: Euro 2024
data.description: Hosted by Germany; Spain wins their 4th Euro title, a new record.

data.title: 2026 World Cup
data.description: The first 48-team tournament, hosted by the USA, Canada, and Mexico.

data.title: Mourinho First Reign
data.description: Jose Mourinho arrives as 'The Special One', winning two consecutive PL titles.

data.title: Chelsea PL Title
data.description: Chelsea win their first top-flight title in 50 years, setting defensive records.

data.title: Antonio Conte Era
data.description: Conte introduces the 3-4-3 to England, winning the Premier League in his first season.

data.title: Drogba's Finale
data.description: Didier Drogba scores the winning penalty in Munich to give Chelsea their first UCL.

data.title: Rafael Benitez Era
data.description: Benitez leads Liverpool to two UCL finals, winning one in 2005.

data.title: The Arne Slot Transition
data.description: Arne Slot succeeds Klopp, implementing a more controlled possession-based style.

data.title: Manuel Pellegrini Reign
data.description: Pellegrini wins a PL title and League Cup double in his debut season with City.

data.title: City 5th PL Title
data.description: Manchester City reclaim the title from Liverpool, starting a period of total dominance.

data.title: Erling Haaland Signing
data.description: City sign the Norwegian striker, who goes on to break the PL single-season goal record.

data.title: Louis van Gaal FA Cup
data.description: Van Gaal wins the FA Cup before being replaced, ending a 3-year trophy drought.

data.title: Jose Mourinho Man Utd Era
data.description: Mourinho wins the Europa League and League Cup, finishing 2nd in the PL.

data.title: Ole Gunnar Solskjaer Era
data.description: The former striker returns as manager, leading the club to back-to-back top-4 finishes.

data.title: Ajax 30th Title
data.description: Ajax win their 30th title, allowing them to wear the 'third star' on their jersey.

data.title: Marcel Keizer Period
data.description: A brief, difficult reign following the Nouri tragedy and Europa League final.

data.title: Erik ten Hag Era
data.description: Ten Hag restores Ajax's domestic dominance and global reputation for attacking play.

data.title: Guus Hiddink Success
data.description: Hiddink's second spell at PSV, reaching the 2005 UCL semi-final.

data.title: Mark van Bommel Reign
data.description: A period of high-intensity football that started with a record-breaking win streak.

data.title: Ruud van Nistelrooy Era
data.description: The legendary striker leads PSV to a KNVB Cup win before a sudden departure.

data.title: Giovanni van Bronckhorst Era
data.description: Gio leads his boyhood club to their first Eredivisie title in the 21st century.

data.title: Feyenoord 16th Title
data.description: Feyenoord win the league with a 3-0 win over Go Ahead Eagles, clinching the trophy.

data.title: Felix Magath Bayern Era
data.description: Magath wins consecutive domestic doubles, a first in German football history.

data.title: Louis van Gaal Bayern Era
data.description: Van Gaal introduces a possession style and promotes youth like Muller and Alaba.

data.title: Jupp Heynckes Treble Era
data.description: Heynckes leads Bayern to a historic clean sweep of all major trophies in 2013.

data.title: Pep Guardiola Bayern Era
data.description: Guardiola wins three straight Bundesligas, revolutionizing German tactical play.

data.title: Hansi Flick Sextuple
data.description: Flick takes over mid-season and wins every possible trophy in a calendar year.

data.title: Thomas Tuchel Period
data.description: A turbulent era including a last-minute title win in 2023 and a UCL semi-final.

data.title: Thomas Tuchel BVB Era
data.description: Tuchel wins the DFB-Pokal and maintains Dortmund's status as a top European side.

data.title: Marco Rose Era
data.description: A single-season reign focused on transition after the departure of Jadon Sancho.

data.title: Edin Terzic Reign
data.description: The fan-favorite coach leads BVB to a UCL final and a narrow title miss in 2023.

data.title: Leverkusen Undefeated Season
data.description: Bayer Leverkusen become the first team in Bundesliga history to finish a season unbeaten.

data.title: Frank Rijkaard Era
data.description: Rijkaard builds the team around Ronaldinho, winning the 2006 Champions League.

data.title: Luis Enrique Era
data.description: The MSN (Messi, Suarez, Neymar) era results in a second historic treble in 2015.

data.title: Xavi Hernandez Era
data.description: The legendary midfielder returns to coach, winning La Liga in his first full season.

data.title: Hansi Flick Barca Era
data.description: Flick brings 'Gegenpressing' to Barcelona, leading to a strong 2024/25 start.

data.title: Jose Mourinho Real Era
data.description: Mourinho ends Barca's dominance by winning the 'League of Records' with 100 points.

data.title: Carlo Ancelotti Second Spell
data.description: Ancelotti returns to win two more UCL titles and multiple La Liga trophies.

data.title: Atleti 11th Title
data.description: Luis Suarez scores the winner on the final day to secure the title for Simeone.

data.title: Antonio Conte Juve Era
data.description: Conte starts the nine-year streak, including an undefeated 2011/12 season.

data.title: Massimiliano Allegri First Reign
data.description: Allegri wins five consecutive doubles and reaches two Champions League finals.

data.title: Maurizio Sarri Year
data.description: Sarri wins the final title of the nine-year run before being replaced by Pirlo.

data.title: Antonio Conte Inter Era
data.description: Conte breaks Juventus' streak by winning the Scudetto with Inter Milan.

data.title: Simone Inzaghi Era
data.description: Inzaghi wins multiple cups and the 20th league title, reaching a UCL final.

data.title: Carlo Ancelotti Milan Era
data.description: A legendary era winning two UCL titles (2003, 2007) and one Serie A title.

data.title: Stefano Pioli Era
data.description: Pioli stabilizes Milan and leads them to the 2022 Scudetto.

data.title: Paulo Fonseca Era
data.description: Fonseca takes over the Rossoneri to lead a new tactical cycle.

data.title: Spain's Global Reign
data.description: Spain becomes the first team to win three major international trophies in a row.

data.title: The Mineirazo
data.description: Germany beats hosts Brazil 7-1, the most shocking result in World Cup history.

data.title: England's Penalty Heartbreak
data.description: Italy defeats England at Wembley on penalties, extending England's trophy wait.

data.title: The Greatest Final Ever
data.description: Argentina beat France 4-2 on penalties after a 3-3 draw in Lusail.

data.title: World Cup 48-Team Kickoff
data.description: The first match of the expanded 48-team World Cup takes place in Mexico City.

description: Major events in five European Football leagues, their Top-3 clubs and some international tournaments
